topics.body:
I personally believe there is _something_ out there, that we can't see.
I don't discredit science, and I certainly don't follow any organized religions like Christianity. But the subjects of death and consciousness have always intrigued me.
But I'm not going to go on a rant about my beliefs right now.

topics.body:
I believe that the afterlife does exist.
But not in the way we think we know.

I prefer to believe that Hell is more like a jail. You get sent there, get punished for your crimes and when you reached an understanding for what was wrong, you are released from Hell.
And for Heaven, I don't want to believe that it a place for eternal happiness. I prefer to believe that it's more like a dream, a memory of sorts as we go to eternal sleep, our souls and bodies laid to rest, forever smiling.

topics.body:
"@MoogSourceVermona":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a3258a63687267750006c6#post_55a3258a63687267750006c6
Here's my thoughts on this:
Personally I think "God/s" is a outside entity of the known universe.  The reason why he doesn't interfere is because of time.

When you get down to it a outside interfering with a universe is *BEYOND* unethical because time isn't a direction or a motion; rather it's frozen.  The best analogy for what time is a frozen river.  From the inside perspective we think that it is moving when in reality it's frozen solid.  From a inside perspective things are moving.  From a outside observer's perspective the universe is a giant particle with 10^81 particles in it that flashed and died.  From a inside perspective things are happening.  From a outside perspective everything has having happening happened already, not yet and is happening.

Every time a outside observer changes something from happening they in turn change a event that has already happened already.


To put it in a much simpler context congratulations you killed hitler, on the other hand you've also killed all the people that were born during the baby boomer generation that wouldn't have been born if not for WWII by preventing them from ever being born and in turn killed all their children and killed all their grandchildren.

Since we're experiencing the universe it's ethical for us to change our fate, but for outside observers it's not ethical because they already know everything that is to happen so they can see all the people that would get wiped from reality if they interfere.

To put it another way the most likely reason why haven't seen any time travelers is because every time you save one person you kill hundreds others in the future.  The only time it would be ethical for outside observers to change past events would be in events that are endangering the whole universe.


Tl:dr; the universe is like a book; sure you may feel as though things are happening when you read it, but the second it's printed everything it is already having happened.

topics.author: 500b587e7f123b1f230014a9

topics.body:
See, my belief in something outside the realm of reality comes from the problem of _what_ consciousness is. I firmly believe that science _can_ explain why we behave in certain ways, or how our brain works, or why our brain perceives things in certain ways and so on. But what even _is_ perception? What does it actually mean to feel something? How do we know that we see things in the same way? _How do we even know that everyone around us doesn't live in their own universe, completely unaware of the true lives of others?_
I don't even know how to put my thoughts into words right now.
topics.author: 53f29d1b6368725f76ba0100

topics.body: IT'S HAPPENING AGAIN

topics.body:
"@Too_Offensive":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a32ae2636872482f001213#post_55a32ae2636872482f001213
That is actually a good point.  The invention of time travel, even if successful, would in the future cause untold numbers of deaths from all the people whose lives have been changed.

If you were already in the future, ignoring the grandfather paradox, if you're far enough in the future say 100,000 years time traveling and changing one person's life could wipe out your original home time's entire population.

topics.body:
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a32c2863687251bf0005e1#post_55a32c2863687251bf0005e1
[bq="Princess♠Molestia"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55a32bb963687251bf00054a#post_55a32bb963687251bf00054a
Lets make this more complicated! Multiverse theory![/bq]
There's evidence of other universes (indentation on the universe, don't ask it would take about a hour and a half to explain), *BUT* we don't have any evidence to support the idea of parallel universes.

More than likely there are unlimited number of other universes, but more than likely they're completely different universes *NOT* different timelines.
